The selective hydrogenation of dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate (TDC) to methyl cyclohexyl-2,4-dicarbamate (HTDC) is an important process for non-phosgene synthesis of methylcyclohexane-2,4-diisocyanate (HTDI). We prepared Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with an Rh particle size of 1.8–6.7 nm and studied size effect on TDC selective hydrogenation. The results showed that the catalytic activities of Rh/γ-Al2O3 increase monotonously with increasing Rh particle size. This demonstrated that Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst dedicates a negative size effect or an antipathetic structure sensitivity. Based on the characterization, we found that the geometric property of Rh is the main factor affecting the activity of catalyst. Combined with the proposed Rh particle model, it was inferred that the Rh (111) plays a major role in the TDC selective hydrogenation and the terrace sites are beneficial to promote the adsorption of TDC. The study on size effect can provide a guidance for the design and preparation of highly efficient Rh-based catalysts for TDC selective hydrogenation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate Selective hydrogenation Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Size effect Electronic property Geometric property Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methyl cyclohexane-2,4-diisocyanate (HTDI) is an upgraded chemical of toluene diisocyanate (TDI). The polyurethane products derived from HTDI possess excellent characteristics such as non-yellowing, light stability, weather resistance and high mechanical properties [1]. At present, HTDI is commercially produced by a phosgene process ( Fig. 1(a)), which suffers from serious environmental and safety problems [2]. In order to overcome these shortcomings, our group proposed a green HTDI synthesis route (Fig. 1(b)) [1]. This route includes three steps: a methoxycarbonylation of toluene-2,4-diamine (TDA) with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) to dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate (TDC), a selective hydrogenation of TDC to methyl cyclohexyl-2,4-dicarbamate (HTDC), and a cleavage of HTDC to HTDI. Among them, the preparation of HTDC by TDC selective hydrogenation is an important step to convert the aromatics to the alicyclics. Supported metal catalysts are often used in hydrogenation reaction and the metal particle size usually affects the catalytic activity. The change in the metal particle size alters the number of different surface sites, that is, terrace sites, edge sites and corner sites. These different surface sites have different coordination environments and electronic properties, resulting in different abilities of adsorption/desorption and bond-breaking/bond-forming, and thus varied catalytic performances. This is so-called "size effect" [3–7]. For example, Ru catalyzed ammonia synthesis [8], Pt catalyzed furfural decarbonization and hydrogenation [9], and Pt or Pd catalyzed CO oxidation [10,11]. At present, there is no report on the size effect in TDC selective hydrogenation reaction. The studies on the size effect of selective hydrogenation of other aromatics can be helpful to this work. Pan et al. [12] prepared Rh/CNT catalysts with an Rh particle size of 2.3, 4.5 and 7.8 nm, respectively. They found that the catalysts showed a negative size effect on the xylene hydrogenation. With the enlargement of Rh particle size from 2.3 to 7.8 nm, the turnover frequencies (TOF) of o-xylene, m-xylene and p-xylene hydrogenation increased from 550 to 761 h−1, 609 to 866 h−1 and 713 to 918 h−1, respectively. Ke et al. [13] prepared Rh/SiO2 catalysts with an Rh particle size from 1 to 3.5 nm and found that Rh showed a negative size effect in the hydrogenation of p-toluidine. With increasing Rh particle size, the catalytic activity enhanced gradually and the maximum value of TOF appeared at an Rh particle size of 3.5 nm. In addition, the hydrogenation of benzene and toluene on Pt [14] and Ni [15] catalysts were also considered to be structure-sensitive reactions. In this work, Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with an Rh particle size of 1.8–6.7 nm were prepared and the size effect of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for TDC selective hydrogenation was investigated. A significant size dependence was observed: with increasing Rh particle size, Rh/γ-Al2O3 showed a negative size effect on the TDC selective hydrogenation. Combined with the catalyst characterization, it was found that the proportion of terrace sites gradually increased while those of edge sites and corner sites gradually decreased with increasing Rh particle size. It was inferred based on the Rh crystal model that Rh (111) is the main active facet for TDC selective hydrogenation. The Rh particle of 6.7 nm has a high proportion of terrace sites and can promote the adsorption of TDC, thus making the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst acquire the highest TOF. The study of Rh particle size effect can provide support for the design and preparation of highly efficient Rh-based catalysts for TDC selective hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Rhodium (III) chloride hydrate (RhCl3⋅xH2O), γ-Al2O3, and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Ethylene glycol (EG) was supplied by Meryer Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Ethanol absolute was bought from Tianjin Guangshunda Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), NaOH and glucose were purchased from Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without a further purification. The TDC was self-made by a reaction of TDI with methanol. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Rh particles with different sizes were synthesized by both an alkali-ethylene glycol method and a sol-gel method, respectively. Then they were supported on γ-Al2O3 to prepare Rh/γ-Al2O3-X catalysts with a same Rh loading (5 wt%) but different Rh particle sizes (X is Rh particle size). The Rh particles with a size of 1.8, 2.6, 3.5 and 4.1 nm were prepared by the alkali-ethylene glycol method using ethylene glycol (EG) as a reducing agent by changing the concentration of precursor, water content of EG solution, the quantity of PVP, reaction temperature and time. Taking the preparation of Rh/γ-Al2O3-2.6 catalyst as an example, the procedures are described as follows. 0.05 g of RhCl3 xH2O was dissolved in 5 mL of EG, then NaOH was added to adjust the pH of solution to 10, followed by an ultrasonic dispersion to make the solid fully dissolved. The mixed solution was heated to 160 ℃ while stirring and maintained for 3 h, then cooled to room temperature and a black solution was obtained. The Rh particles with a size of 2.6 nm were obtained by centrifugation and re-dispersed into 10 mL of acetone. After that, γ-Al2O3 was added and stirred for 8 h. Then the solid was separated out from the mixture, dried in a vacuum at 80 ℃ for 6 h and calcined at 450 ℃ for 4 h to attain the Rh/γ-Al2O3-2.6 catalyst. The Rh particles of 6.7 nm were prepared by the sol-gel method using glucose as a complexing agent, PVP as a surfactant and ethanol aqueous solution (5 mL of anhydrous ethanol and 2 mL of water) as a solvent. The preparation of Rh/γ-Al2O3-6.7 catalyst is as follows: 0.02 g of RhCl3·xH2O, 0.05 g of glucose and 0.05 g of PVP were dissolved in an ethanol aqueous solution, then followed by an ultrasonic dispersion for 10 min until the solid powder was completely dissolved. After stirring at 30 ℃ for 3 h, 0.16 g of γ-Al2O3 was added and ultrasonically dispersed for 10 min. Then the mixture was heated to 90 ℃ while stirring for 3 h. The solid obtained from the mixture was dried in a vacuum at 80 ℃ for 6 h, and finally calcined at 450 ℃ for 4 h to attain the Rh/γ-Al2O3-6.7 catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal structures of the samples were analyzed by an X-ray diffraction (XRD) instrument equipped with Cu Kα radiation and operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The patterns were recorded at a scanning rate of 6 °/min and within a scanning range of 2θ = 10–90°. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to determine the concentration of Rh in the studied samples. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured using an ASAP 2020M+C autosorption analyzer. The Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) and Barrett Joyner Helenda (BJH) methods were separately used to calculate the specific surface area, the pore volume and pore size of the samples. The morphology and size of Rh particles were observed by a FEI Talos F200 transmission electron microscope. The samples were dispersed in anhydrous ethanol by ultrasonic operation and a small amount of liquid was dropped into the copper grid covered with ultra-thin carbon film. The dispersion of Rh was performed by CO pulse chemisorption carried out in an AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption analyzer. At 300 °C, 80 mL/min He was purged and degassed for 60 min to remove impurities adsorbed on the catalyst surface. After that, the catalyst was cooled to 40 °C in flowing He. For CO chemisorption, the sample was pulsed using a mixture of 5 % CO/He. When the pulse peak intensity does not change, that is, the catalyst is adsorbed to saturation and the CO adsorption capacity of the sample is obtained. Assuming that Rh is hemispherical, the dispersion of Rh can be calculated by the following equation [16]: (1) D = 6 M δ ρ d p N 0 where, M is the molecular weight of Rh (102.91 g/mol), dp is the average diameter of Rh particles measured by TEM (nm), ρ is the Rh metal density (12.4 g/cm3), δ is the area occupied by a surface Rh atom (7.58 A2/atom) and N0 is the Avogadro constant. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded by an ESCALAB 250Xi equipped with Al Kα source for analyzing the surface element chemical states. The binding energy of C 1s signal at 284.8 eV from adventitious carbon was used to calibrate the effect of surface charge. The temperature programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD) was carried out in an AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption analyzer. The catalyst sample was exposed to H2 of 30 mL/min for 30 min, then purged for 30 min with 30 mL/min of He, and heated to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min for desorption. The adsorption behavior of CO on Rh/γ-Al2O3 was studied by CO diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS). The sample was treated with N2 at a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 200 ℃ for 2 h, then cooled to 50 ℃ and the background spectrum was collected. The catalyst sample was exposed to 5 % CO/He at a flow rate of 30 mL/min for 30 min until saturated. The catalyst sample was purged for 15 min with N2 in order to remove the unadsorbed or weakly adsorbed CO. The spectra were collected by 256 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation and product analysis The selective catalytic hydrogenation of TDC was carried out in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave. In this process, 0.4 g of TDC and 0.04 g of catalyst with a mesh of 60–80 were charged into the reactor lined with teflon, followed by the addition of 8 mL of DMC solvent. After the reactor was sealed, the residual air inside was removed by introducing H2 for three times. Then the reactor was pressurized to 3 MPa with H2 and kept at 50–80 ℃ for 1 h while stirring at 700 r/min. After the reaction, the solvent was removed using a rotary evaporator. The product was analyzed by a high performance liquid chromatograph (Waters 1515) equipped with a differential refractive detector (Waters 2414). The chromatographic analysis conditions were as follows: a SunFire XDB-C18 (4.6 × 250 mm, 5 µm) chromatographic column at a column temperature of 35 ℃, a mobile phase of acetonitrile/water with a volumetric ratio of 2/3 at a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min, and an injection volume of 20 μL. TDC conversion (XTDC), HTDC yield (YHTDC), HTDC selectivity (SHTDC) and turnover frequency (TOF) of TDC selective hydrogenation were calculated using the following Eqs. (2)–(5): (2) X TDC = ( m 0 − m 1 ) × 100 % m 0 (3) Y HTDC = m 2 × 238.24 m 0 × 244.3 (4) S HTDC = Y HTDC X TDC where, m0 and m1 are the weight of TDC before and after the reaction, respectively (g); m2 is the weight of HTDC produced from TDC hydrogenation (g); 238.24 and 244.3 are the relative molecular weight of TDC and HTDC, respectively (g/mol). (5) TOF = N TDC N Rh × t = m 0 × X TDC M TDC m ca × Rh l × D M Rh × t Where, NTDC is the number of moles of TDC reacted; NRh is the number of moles of Rh on the surface of catalyst; m0 is the weight of TDC before the reaction (g); mca is the weight of catalyst (g); Rhl is the loading of Rh in the catalyst (%); D is the dispersion of Rh in the catalyst (%); XTDC is the conversion of TDC (%); MTDC is the relative molecular weight of TDC (238.24 g/mol); MRh is the molar weight of Rh (102.9 g/mol); t is reaction time (h). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts The morphologies of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with five different Rh particle sizes were characterized by TEM and the results are shown in Fig. 2(a–e). The Rh particles with different sizes were well dispersed on γ-Al2O3 with regular morphology and no obvious agglomeration. By calculating at least 100 particles in different regions of each sample in TEM images, the Rh particles sizes were estimated and the histograms of particle size distribution are inserted in Fig. 2(a’–e’). The average particle sizes of Rh particles in different samples varied from 1.8 to 6.7 nm, and the size distributions were narrow. The HRTEM images of catalysts with five different Rh particle sizes are shown in Fig. 3(a–e). Except for the particle of 1.8 nm, all the particles with different Rh particle sizes had a lattice fringe of 0.218 nm, corresponding to the Rh (111) plane [17]. The Rh particles showed a shape similar to a polygon due to the influence of the projection angle, and they were inferred to be a truncated octahedron. The texture properties, metal particle sizes, loading and dispersion of the catalysts with different Rh particle sizes are summarized in Table 1. The five catalysts had similar specific surface areas in a range from 143.4 to 149.5 m2/g. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts with five different Rh particle sizes are shown in Fig. S1 (a–e) in the Supporting information. According to IUPAC classification, the five samples showed IV type adsorption isotherms and H3 type hysteresis loops at the P/P0 about 0.7–1.0. From the BJH pore size distribution (Fig. S2), it could be seen that the pore sizes of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were in a range from 2 to 30 nm, indicating that Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts possessed mainly mesoporous structures. The dispersion of Rh particles calculated from Eq. (1) decreased from 60.62 % to 16.29 % when the Rh particle sizes increased from 1.8 to 6.7 nm. The crystallographic structures of the catalysts were analyzed by X-ray diffractometer and the results are shown in Fig. 4. The diffraction peaks appeared respectively at 2θ = 37.6°, 39.5°, 45.7°, 60.8° and 67.0° could be attributed to the (311), (222), (400), (511) and (440) planes of γ-Al2O3, being consistent with the standard card (PDF # 10-0425). There was no diffraction peak of Rh, indicating that Rh particles were small and were well dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 [18]. 3.2 Size effect of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in TDC selective hydrogenation The influences of the external and internal diffusion on TDC selective hydrogenation were investigated and the results showed that they could be eliminated using the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with a mesh of 60–80, at a stirring speed of 700 rpm, under the conditions of 50–80 ℃, 3 MPa hydrogen pressure and TDC/catalyst weight ratio of 10. Then the catalytic performances of Rh/γ-Al2O3-X catalysts with different Rh particle sizes were evaluated for TDC selective hydrogenation and the results are shown in Fig. 5(a) and Table S1. In addition, the TDC conversion and HTDC yield versus reaction time are shown in Fig. S3 (a–b). Compared with other catalysts, Rh/γ-Al2O3-1.8 gave better catalytic activity at the same reaction time. The reaction rates of TDC selective hydrogenation at different temperatures for 1 h were calculated, and the results are shown in Fig. 5(b). With increasing Rh particle sizes from 1.8 to 6.7 nm, the reaction rates of the catalysts decreased and the activity of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with 1.8 nm was also the best. According to the behavior of catalyst, heterogeneous catalytic reactions can be classified into structure-sensitive reaction (TOF value is related to catalyst sizes) and structure-insensitive reaction (TOF value is independent of catalyst sizes) [5]. According to the changes of TOF with the catalyst sizes, the reaction can be divided into three types: TOF value increases with increasing the metal size (negative size effect) [12], TOF value decreases with increasing the metal size (positive size effect) [8], or TOF value shows a maximum with increasing the metal size (volcano change) [3]. In order to clarify the size effect of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in TDC selective hydrogenation, the variations of the catalytic activity of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with reaction temperature were studied and further the reaction kinetics were discussed for exploring the difference of catalytic activities of catalysts. For comparison, two methods [19] were employed to calculate the TOF of TDC selective hydrogenation catalyzed by Rh/γ-Al2O3: the first one is the dispersity method and the TOF and Ea are marked as TOF1 and Ea 1 , and another one is the surface atom number method and the TOF and Ea are marked as TOF2 and Ea 2 . The variation of TOF1 with Rh particle sizes is shown in Fig. 6(a). In the range of 1.8–6.7 nm, TOF1 increased with increasing Rh particle size, indicating that Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation showed a negative size effect. A plot of Ln(TOF) with 1000/T for each Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst followed a good linear relationship, and the activation energy (Ea) was calculated from the corresponding slope [20]. As shown in Fig. 6(b–c), the variation of Ea 1 showed an opposite trend to TOF1 and the minimum value was 13.8 kJ/mol on Rh/γ-Al2O3-6.7 catalyst. The change of TOF2 with Rh particle sizes is shown in Fig. S4 (a) in the Supporting information. Similarly, TOF2 increased with increasing Rh particle size, indicating that Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation showed a negative size effect. As shown in Fig. S4 (b–c) in the Supporting information, Ea 2 showed an opposite trend to TOF2 either, and the minimum value was 14.0 kJ/mol on Rh/γ-Al2O3-6.7 catalyst. The calculation results of the two methods listed in Table 2 showed that the two TOF values were approximate and gave a similar trend with the variation of Rh particle size. It is inferred that there is a negative size effect for Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation. The low Ea value showed that the TDC selective hydrogenation can be carried out easily over Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Van Hardeveld [21] found that the proportions of different surface atoms varied in their number and arrangement with changing the nickel particle sizes, thus affecting the catalytic performance of the nickel-based catalyst. In this work, we studied the relationship of the proportions of different surface atoms with Rh particle size, explored the effect of different active sites on the catalytic activity, and then made clear the active sites of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation. According to the results of HRTEM, the morphology of Rh particle was approximately treated as a truncated octahedron, as shown in Fig. S5 in the Supporting information. There are three kinds of possible active sites on the Rh particle surface: (1) the red atoms at the corner are the corner sites, and (2) the yellow atoms at the edge are the edge sites, both of which belong to the low coordination sites, and (3) the blue atoms at the surface are the terrace sites which belong to the high coordination sites. According to the references [22,23], there is a method for calculating the number of surface atoms and sites and the formulas are shown in Table S2. The relationship of the particle sizes and proportions of corner sites, edge sites, (111) and (100) plane sites in different Rh particles sizes could be calculated, and the results are shown in Fig. 7(a). With increasing Rh particle size, the proportions of atoms at the corner sites and edge sites decreased while those of atoms on the (100) and (111) planes increased. Based on the number of atoms on different sites in the Rh particles of different sizes (Fig. 7(a)), the reaction rates of TDC selective hydrogenation at 50 ℃ for 1 h were used as an activity index of the catalyst to calculate the TOFi of different sites, the formulas are shown in Table S3. When the contribution of a kind of active sites to the catalytic activity is dominant, the reaction rate based on this kind of active sites is constant, that is, the normalized TOF is size-independent [23]. The TOF was normalized according to Table S3. After normalization, the catalytic activities of the corner sites, edge sites, (111) and (100) surfaces of the catalysts with different Rh particle sizes were obtained. The normalized TOF of different sites on the Rh particles with different sizes are shown in Fig. 7(b). It can be seen that there was an obvious constant region for TOF111, suggesting that Rh (111) is the main plane affecting the catalytic activity of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. That is, the Rh (111) played a major catalytic role in the TDC selective hydrogenation, which may be the main reason why the highest TOF was obtained on Rh/γ-Al2O3-6.7. The TEM images and particle size distributions of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes after reaction were tested and the results are shown in Fig. S6. It can be seen that there is no significant change in the size and morphology of Rh particles after reaction, indicating that the size and morphology of Rh nanoparticles can remain stable during the reaction. In addition, The Rh contents in the catalysts before and after the reaction are shown in Table S4. It can be observed that there is no obvious decline in the Rh loading, indicating that there is almost no loss of Rh during the reaction. The catalytic performances of the Rh particles with different sizes were evaluated. The recovered catalysts were washed with hot DMC and dried after reaction and re-used in the next run to investigate the stability of the catalysts. The results are shown in Table S5 in the Supporting information. It was found that the catalytic activities of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particles sizes were significantly different in the recycle use. In the Ref. [1], it was proved that the coverage of the active sites with some organic species in the supported Rh catalyst was the main reason for the catalyst deactivation. The organic species can not be completely removed out by DMC washing and drying. More active sites were covered with an increase in the recycle of the catalyst, leading to a decrease in catalytic activity. Qu et al. [24] in our group studied the performance of supported Rh catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation reaction and found that Rh3+ is the catalytic active site in the supported Rh catalyst. In the stability experiments in this work, the catalyst will be reduced by hydrogen several times during the recycle use process, resulting in a decrease of the content of Rh3+ and an increase of the content of Rh0 gradually. The above factors may be the reasons for the unstable activities of the catalysts. 3.3 Factors influencing the size effect of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts For supported metal catalysts, electronic properties and/or geometric ones of metal have an important influence on the activity of catalyst [5]. The electronic and geometric properties of Rh can be changed by adjusting Rh particle sizes. The chemical states of Rh with different sizes were studied by XPS analyses. The XPS spectra of Rh 3d in Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes before and after reaction are shown in Fig. 8(a–b). Compared with the spectra of Rh 3d before reaction, the binding energy of Rh 3d of Rh catalysts shifted 1.6 eV to the lower direction as a whole after reaction. The results showed that the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts sizes were easily reduced by hydrogen in the reaction process, making the binding energy shift to a lower direction. In the Rh 3d XPS spectra of the synthesized catalysts, the characteristic peaks of Rh0, Rh3+ and Rh4+ appeared at 307.0–307.5 eV, 308.1–308.9 eV and 309.4–310.2 eV, respectively [25]. The Rh 3d XPS spectra in Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes were fitted before and after reaction, and the results are shown in Fig. S7 (a–e) and Fig. S7 (f–j), respectively. The results of Rh 3d XPS spectra of Rh catalysts before and after reaction are listed in Table 3. Rhn+/(Rhn++Rh0) decreased gradually from 92.0 % to 81.0 % with increasing Rh particle sizes before reaction. However, Rh appeared mainly in the form of Rhn+ in the Rh particles with different sizes. This phenomenon could be attributed to the metal-support interaction. For a small Rh particle, the formation of more Rhn+ species is favored since the interaction of small Rh particle with γ-Al2O3 is stronger, facilitating the formation of more low-coordination sites [4]. After reaction, the 3d binding energy of Rh0 and Rh3+ decreased about 0.2–0.4 eV and Rhn+/(Rhn+ + Rh0) declined gradually from 42.1 % to 39.0 % with increasing Rh particle sizes. This indicates that Rh particles were reduced by hydrogen during reaction, and further a significant decrease in Rhn+ content and a higher content of Rh0 were reached after reaction. In addition, high density of moderate-strong acid sites on γ-Al2O3 surface is beneficial to withdraw electrons from Rh so as to form an electron-deficient Rh surface, thus promoting the adsorption of reactants [24,26]. Therefore, the electronic property of Rh will affect TDC selective hydrogenation. However, the order of Rhn+/(Rhn+ + Rh0) of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes were not in an agreement with the order of TDC selective hydrogenation performance. So it is inferred that the electronic property is not the decisive factor for TDC selective hydrogenation, and the catalytic activity is mainly affected by the geometric property of Rh particles. With changing the Rh particle sizes, the proportions of different surface sites (corner sites, edge sites and terrace sites) will change, which may be an important factor affecting the performance of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for TDC selective hydrogenation. We employed the diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra obtained using CO as a probe (CO-DRIFTS) to distinguish the adsorption sites on Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh sizes. In the CO-DRIFTS spectra of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts (as shown in Fig. 9), there was a CO gas phase absorption band at 2100–2200 cm−1. The absorption peaks of CO at 2086 cm−1 and 2015 cm−1 belong separately to the symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching peaks of Rh(CO)2 species, in which two CO molecules are absorbed by one Rh atom and the band of the carbonyl species responds to a constant wavenumber, independent of the Rh particle size [27,28]. The peak at 2060 cm−1 is ascribed to CO linear adsorption, which may be due to the adsorption of CO on Rh3+ or Rh2+ species [27]. The broad absorption band centered at 1875 cm−1 can be attributed to the bridged CO on the terrace sites of Rh particles [27,29]. It is worth noting that the relative intensities of the absorption bands of the linear (2060 cm−1) and bridged CO (1875 cm−1) at the Rh sites were raised with increasing Rh particle size. And the bridged adsorption intensity of CO at the terrace sites of Rh particles increased with increasing Rh particle size, indicating that the large Rh particles have more terrace sites. This is consistent with the calculation results of the crystal model. H2-TPD test was carried out on Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes, and the results are shown in Fig. 10. The peaks of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes were similar and no hydrogen desorption peaks attributed to weak adsorption below 100 ℃ existed, indicating that Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Rh particle sizes have no weakly adsorbed hydrogen. The desorption peak temperatures of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are mainly at 100–500 ℃. The desorption peak at 150 ℃ is attributed to the desorption of hydrogen on the Rh surface [30], which is the hydrogen adsorbed at the terrace sites. With increasing Rh particle size, the peak area at this temperature gradually is augmented, indicating that the number of terrace sites increases. For the 1.8 nm Rh particles no obvious peaks in this temperature appear, indicating that less proportion of terrace sites exists in the small particles. This is consistent with the results of CO-DRIFTS. We concluded based on the results of both CO-DRIFTS and H2-TPD analyses that the proportion of terrace sites increases with increasing Rh particle size, resulting in negative size effect since Rh (111) is the main facet affecting the catalytic activity of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this work, Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with an Rh particle size in the range of 1.8–6.7 nm were prepared and the size effect of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation was studied. The results showed that the TOF and Ea of TDC selective hydrogenation were significantly size-dependent: Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyzed TDC selective hydrogenation reaction showed a negative size effect when the Rh particle sizes increased from 1.8 to 6.7 nm. The variation trend of Ea was opposite to TOF and the minimum value was 13.8 kJ/mol at Rh/γ-Al2O3-6.7. Combined with the characterization results, we inferred that the geometric property of Rh is the main factors affecting the activity of the catalysts. The enlargement of Rh particle sizes can increase the proportion of terrace sites and decrease the proportion of corner and edge sites. Combined with the crystal model, it was found that the Rh (111) played a leading role in the TDC selective hydrogenation. Compared with the corner and edge sites, the terrace sites were the main active sites for the TDC selective hydrogenation. Terrace sites were more conducive to the adsorption and activation of TDC, thus showing a negative size effect. This study revealed the effect of Rh particle sizes on the performance of TDC selective hydrogenation, and provided theoretical guidance for the reasonable design of highly efficient Rh-based catalysts for TDC hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of dimethyl toluene-2,4-dicarbamate (TDC) to methyl cyclohexyl-2,4-dicarbamate (HTDC) is an important process for non-phosgene synthesis of methylcyclohexane-2,4-diisocyanate (HTDI). We prepared Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with an Rh particle size of 1.8–6.7 nm and studied size effect on TDC selective hydrogenation. The results showed that the catalytic activities of Rh/γ-Al2O3 increase monotonously with increasing Rh particle size. This demonstrated that Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst dedicates a negative size effect or an antipathetic structure sensitivity. Based on the characterization, we found that the geometric property of Rh is the main factor affecting the activity of catalyst. Combined with the proposed Rh particle model, it was inferred that the Rh (111) plays a major role in the TDC selective hydrogenation and the terrace sites are beneficial to promote the adsorption of TDC. The study on size effect can provide a guidance for the design and preparation of highly efficient Rh-based catalysts for TDC selective hydrogenation.
